segment.source: Use AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies in the same domain (Windows 10)
segment.target: Use AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies in the same domain (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals describes concepts and procedures to help you manage your application control strategy using Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals describes concepts and procedures to help you manage your application control strategy using Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker.

segment.source: Use AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies in the same domain
segment.target: Use AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies in the same domain

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals describes concepts and procedures to help you manage your application control strategy using Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals describes concepts and procedures to help you manage your application control strategy using Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker.

segment.source: Using AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies in the same domain
segment.target: Using AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies in the same domain

segment.source: AppLocker is supported on systems running Windows 7 and above.
segment.target: AppLocker is supported on systems running Windows 7 and above.

segment.source: Software Restriction Policies (SRP) is supported on systems running Windows Vista or earlier.
segment.target: Software Restriction Policies (SRP) is supported on systems running Windows Vista or earlier.

segment.source: You can continue to use SRP for application control on your pre-Windows 7 computers, but use AppLocker for computers running Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7 and later.
segment.target: You can continue to use SRP for application control on your pre-Windows 7 computers, but use AppLocker for computers running Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7 and later.

segment.source: It is recommended that you author AppLocker and SRP rules in separate GPOs and target the GPO with SRP policies to systems running Windows Vista or earlier.
segment.target: It is recommended that you author AppLocker and SRP rules in separate GPOs and target the GPO with SRP policies to systems running Windows Vista or earlier.

segment.source: When both SRP and AppLocker policies are applied to computers running Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7 and later, the SRP policies are ignored.
segment.target: When both SRP and AppLocker policies are applied to computers running Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7 and later, the SRP policies are ignored.

segment.source: The following table compares the features and functions of Software Restriction Policies (SRP) and AppLocker.
segment.target: The following table compares the features and functions of Software Restriction Policies (SRP) and AppLocker.

segment.source: Application control function
segment.target: Application control function

segment.source: SRP
segment.target: SRP

segment.source: AppLocker
segment.target: AppLocker

segment.source: Scope
segment.target: Scope

segment.source: SRP policies can be applied to all Windows operating systems beginning with Windows XP and Windows Server 2003.
segment.target: SRP policies can be applied to all Windows operating systems beginning with Windows XP and Windows Server 2003.

segment.source: AppLocker policies apply only to Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, and later.
segment.target: AppLocker policies apply only to Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, and later.

segment.source: Policy creation
segment.target: Policy creation

segment.source: SRP policies are maintained through Group Policy and only the administrator of the GPO can update the SRP policy.
segment.target: SRP policies are maintained through Group Policy and only the administrator of the GPO can update the SRP policy.

segment.source: The administrator on the local computer can modify the SRP policies defined in the local GPO.
segment.target: The administrator on the local computer can modify the SRP policies defined in the local GPO.

segment.source: AppLocker policies are maintained through Group Policy and only the administrator of the GPO can update the policy.
segment.target: AppLocker policies are maintained through Group Policy and only the administrator of the GPO can update the policy.

segment.source: The administrator on the local computer can modify the AppLocker policies defined in the local GPO.
segment.target: The administrator on the local computer can modify the AppLocker policies defined in the local GPO.

segment.source: AppLocker permits customization of error messages to direct users to a Web page for help.
segment.target: AppLocker permits customization of error messages to direct users to a Web page for help.

segment.source: Policy maintenance
segment.target: Policy maintenance

segment.source: SRP policies must be updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (if the policies are created locally) or the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
segment.target: SRP policies must be updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (if the policies are created locally) or the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).

segment.source: AppLocker policies can be updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (if the policies are created locally), or the GPMC, or the Windows PowerShell AppLocker cmdlets.
segment.target: AppLocker policies can be updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (if the policies are created locally), or the GPMC, or the Windows PowerShell AppLocker cmdlets.

segment.source: Policy application
segment.target: Policy application

segment.source: SRP policies are distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: SRP policies are distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: AppLocker policies are distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: AppLocker policies are distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Enforcement mode
segment.target: Enforcement mode

segment.source: SRP works in the “deny list mode” where administrators can create rules for files that they do not want to allow in this Enterprise whereas the rest of the file are allowed to run by default.
segment.target: SRP works in the “deny list mode” where administrators can create rules for files that they do not want to allow in this Enterprise whereas the rest of the file are allowed to run by default.

segment.source: SRP can also be configured in the “allow list mode” such that the by default all files are blocked and administrators need to create allow rules for files that they want to allow.
segment.target: SRP can also be configured in the “allow list mode” such that the by default all files are blocked and administrators need to create allow rules for files that they want to allow.

segment.source: AppLocker by default works in the “allow list mode” where only those files are allowed to run for which there is a matching allow rule.
segment.target: AppLocker by default works in the “allow list mode” where only those files are allowed to run for which there is a matching allow rule.

segment.source: File types that can be controlled
segment.target: File types that can be controlled

segment.source: SRP can control the following file types:
segment.target: SRP can control the following file types:

segment.source: Executables
segment.target: Executables

segment.source: Dlls
segment.target: Dlls

segment.source: Scripts
segment.target: Scripts

segment.source: Windows Installers
segment.target: Windows Installers

segment.source: SRP cannot control each file type separately.
segment.target: SRP cannot control each file type separately.

segment.source: All SRP rules are in a single rule collection.
segment.target: All SRP rules are in a single rule collection.

segment.source: AppLocker can control the following file types:
segment.target: AppLocker can control the following file types:

segment.source: Executables
segment.target: Executables

segment.source: Dlls
segment.target: Dlls

segment.source: Scripts
segment.target: Scripts

segment.source: Windows Installers
segment.target: Windows Installers

segment.source: Packaged apps and installers
segment.target: Packaged apps and installers

segment.source: AppLocker maintains a separate rule collection for each of the five file types.
segment.target: AppLocker maintains a separate rule collection for each of the five file types.

segment.source: Designated file types
segment.target: Designated file types

segment.source: SRP supports an extensible list of file types that are considered executable.
segment.target: SRP supports an extensible list of file types that are considered executable.

segment.source: Administrators can add extensions for files that should be considered executable.
segment.target: Administrators can add extensions for files that should be considered executable.

segment.source: AppLocker currently supports the following file extensions:
segment.target: AppLocker currently supports the following file extensions:

segment.source: Executables (.exe, .com)
segment.target: Executables (.exe, .com)

segment.source: Dlls (.ocx, .dll)
segment.target: Dlls (.ocx, .dll)

segment.source: Scripts (.vbs, .js, .ps1, .cmd, .bat)
segment.target: Scripts (.vbs, .js, .ps1, .cmd, .bat)

segment.source: Windows Installers (.msi, .mst, .msp)
segment.target: Windows Installers (.msi, .mst, .msp)

segment.source: Packaged app installers (.appx)
segment.target: Packaged app installers (.appx)

segment.source: Rule types
segment.target: Rule types

segment.source: SRP supports four types of rules:
segment.target: SRP supports four types of rules:

segment.source: Hash
segment.target: Hash

segment.source: Path
segment.target: Path

segment.source: Signature
segment.target: Signature

segment.source: Internet zone
segment.target: Internet zone

segment.source: AppLocker supports three types of rules:
segment.target: AppLocker supports three types of rules:

segment.source: File hash
segment.target: File hash

segment.source: Path
segment.target: Path

segment.source: Publisher
segment.target: Publisher

segment.source: Editing the hash value
segment.target: Editing the hash value

segment.source: In Windows XP, you could use SRP to provide custom hash values.
segment.target: In Windows XP, you could use SRP to provide custom hash values.

segment.source: Beginning with Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, you can only select the file to hash, not provide the hash value.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, you can only select the file to hash, not provide the hash value.

segment.source: AppLocker computes the hash value itself.
segment.target: AppLocker computes the hash value itself.

segment.source: Internally, it uses the SHA2 Authenticode hash for Portable Executables (exe and dll) and Windows Installers and a SHA2 flat file hash for the rest.
segment.target: Internally, it uses the SHA2 Authenticode hash for Portable Executables (exe and dll) and Windows Installers and a SHA2 flat file hash for the rest.

segment.source: Support for different security levels
segment.target: Support for different security levels

segment.source: With SRP, you can specify the permissions with which an app can run.
segment.target: With SRP, you can specify the permissions with which an app can run.

segment.source: So, you can configure a rule such that Notepad always runs with restricted permissions and never with administrative privileges.
segment.target: So, you can configure a rule such that Notepad always runs with restricted permissions and never with administrative privileges.

segment.source: SRP on Windows Vista and earlier supported multiple security levels.
segment.target: SRP on Windows Vista and earlier supported multiple security levels.

segment.source: On Windows 7, that list was restricted to just two levels: Disallowed and Unrestricted (Basic User translates to Disallowed).
segment.target: On Windows 7, that list was restricted to just two levels: Disallowed and Unrestricted (Basic User translates to Disallowed).

segment.source: AppLocker does not support security levels.
segment.target: AppLocker does not support security levels.

segment.source: Manage Packaged apps and Packaged app installers.
segment.target: Manage Packaged apps and Packaged app installers.

segment.source: Not supported
segment.target: Not supported

segment.source: .appx is a valid file type which AppLocker can manage.
segment.target: .appx is a valid file type which AppLocker can manage.

segment.source: Targeting a rule to a user or a group of users
segment.target: Targeting a rule to a user or a group of users

segment.source: SRP rules apply to all users on a particular computer.
segment.target: SRP rules apply to all users on a particular computer.

segment.source: AppLocker rules can be targeted to a specific user or a group of users.
segment.target: AppLocker rules can be targeted to a specific user or a group of users.

segment.source: Support for rule exceptions
segment.target: Support for rule exceptions

segment.source: SRP does not support rule exceptions.
segment.target: SRP does not support rule exceptions.

segment.source: AppLocker rules can have exceptions which allow you to create rules such as “Allow everything from Windows except for regedit.exe”.
segment.target: AppLocker rules can have exceptions which allow you to create rules such as “Allow everything from Windows except for regedit.exe”.

segment.source: Support for audit mode
segment.target: Support for audit mode

segment.source: SRP does not support audit mode.
segment.target: SRP does not support audit mode.

segment.source: The only way to test SRP policies is to set up a test environment and run a few experiments.
segment.target: The only way to test SRP policies is to set up a test environment and run a few experiments.

segment.source: AppLocker supports audit mode which allows you to test the effect of their policy in the real production environment without impacting the user experience.
segment.target: AppLocker supports audit mode which allows you to test the effect of their policy in the real production environment without impacting the user experience.

segment.source: Once you are satisfied with the results, you can start enforcing the policy.
segment.target: Once you are satisfied with the results, you can start enforcing the policy.

segment.source: Support for exporting and importing policies
segment.target: Support for exporting and importing policies

segment.source: SRP does not support policy import/export.
segment.target: SRP does not support policy import/export.

segment.source: AppLocker supports the importing and exporting of policies.
segment.target: AppLocker supports the importing and exporting of policies.

segment.source: This allows you to create AppLocker policy on a sample device, test it out and then export that policy and import it back into the desired GPO.
segment.target: This allows you to create AppLocker policy on a sample device, test it out and then export that policy and import it back into the desired GPO.

segment.source: Rule enforcement
segment.target: Rule enforcement

segment.source: Internally, SRP rules enforcement happens in the user-mode which is less secure.
segment.target: Internally, SRP rules enforcement happens in the user-mode which is less secure.

segment.source: Internally, AppLocker rules for .exe and .dll files are enforced in the kernel-mode which is more secure than enforcing them in the user-mode.
segment.target: Internally, AppLocker rules for .exe and .dll files are enforced in the kernel-mode which is more secure than enforcing them in the user-mode.
